questions.text: Which of the following ligament develop in the arrow marked structure
questions.solution:
• The abdominal part of the foregut is suspended by mesenteries both ventrally and dorsally.
  • The ventral mesentery of the foregut is called the ventral mesogastrium, and the dorsal mesentery is called dorsal mesogastrium (gastrium means stomach)
  • The ventral mesogastrium becomes divided by the developing liver into a ventral part and a dorsal part.
  • The ventral part forms the ligaments of the liver, namely:
    • The falciform (Latin sickle-shaped) ligament
    • The right and left triangular ligaments
    • The superior and inferior layers of the coronary ligament
  • The dorsal part of the ventral mesogastrium forms the lesser omentum.
  • The fate of the dorsal mesogastrium is as follows.
    • The greater or caudal part of the dorsal mesogastrium becomes greatly elongated and forms the greater omentum.
    • The spleen develops in relation to the cranial part of the dorsal mesogastrium, and divides it into dorsal and ventral parts.
    • The ventral part forms the gastrosplenic ligament while the dorsal part forms the lienorenal ligament.
    • The cranial most part of the dorsal mesogastrium forms the gastrophrenic ligament.

- Derivatives of mesogastrium are as follow :

questions.text: A patient underwent coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complaint of paraesthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• The great or long saphenous vein is formed by the union of the medial end of dorsal venous arch with the medial marginal vein which drains the medial side of the great
  • It passes upwards in front of the medial malleolus, crosses the lower one-third of the medial surface of the tibia obliquely, and runs along its medial border to reach the back of the knee.
  • The saphenous nerve runs in front of the great saphenous vein.
  • The saphenous nerve is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve
  • It supplies the skin of the medial side of the leg and the medial border of the foot up to the ball of the great toe.

- Cutaneous nerves on front of the leg and dorsum of foot is as follow :

questions.text: Identify the structure in the given diagram
questions.solution:
Key: 1 -Chondrocytes

2 -Ground tissue with collagen fibres

  • Fibrocartilage is characterised by:
  • Presence of prominent collagen fibres arranged in bundles with rows of chondrocytes intervening between the bundles.
  • Perichondrium is absent.
  • This kind of cartilage can be confused with the appearance of a tendon.
  • However the chondrocytes in fibrocartilage are rounded but in a tendon, fibrocytes are flattened and elongated.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination pupillary reaction , light reflex and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario ?
questions.solution:
- The marked nerves in image is as follow :

  1. Optic nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Trigeminal nerve
  4. Facial nerve

- The patient presents with throbbing headache , photophobia and excessive lacrimation so it suggest  that it might suffer from Trigeminal neuralgia.

- Trigeminal neuralgia causes attacks of very severe burning and scalding pain along the distribution of the nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain
questions.solution:
• Congenital cerebral aneurysms:
    • These occur mostly on the vessels of circulus arteriosus, particularly at or near the junction of two arteries involved in the formation of the circle of Willis.
    • The basic abnormality at these points is the congenital deficiency of tunica media in the arterial wall.
    • The aneurysms are berry shaped (saccular) so known as berry or saccular aneurysm.
    • The Subarachnoid haemorrhage commonly results from rupture of these aneurysms.
    • NCCT brain in case of subarachnoid haemorrhages show -star of death appearance

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of motor vehicle accident has presented to casualty with pelvic fracture. His vitals are stable, but he is unable to pass the urine. On examination he has blood at the penile meatus. Angio has been performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury
questions.solution:
• The urethra can also rupture in accidental injuries.
  • Rupture of penile urethra leads to collection of urine in the superficial perineal space.
  • Rupture of membranous urethra causes accumulation of urine in the pelvic cavity.
  • Rupture of the urethra leads to extravasation of urine, which may be superficial or deep.
  • In superficial extravasation, the urine spreads downwards deep to the membranous layer of the superficial fascia. It first fills the superficial perineal space; and then the scrotum, the penis and the lower part of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • It is prevented from going to the ischioanal fossa or the thigh by the firm attachment of the membranous layer of superficial fascia to their boundaries.
  • In deep extravasation, the urine spreads upwards into the extraperitoneal space of the pelvis around the bladder and prostate into the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: Neuromuscular blockade monitoring through adductor pollicis. Which of the following nerves are tested here?
questions.solution:
• Adductor pollicis is supplied by a deep branch of the ulnar
  • Ulnar nerve lies superficial to the flexor retinaculum, covered only by the superficial slip of the retinaculum.
  • It terminates by dividing into a superficial and a deep branch.
  • Superficial branch is cutaneous.
  • The deep branch passes through the muscles of the hypothenar eminence to lie in the concavity of the deep palmar arch to end in the adductor pollicis.

ULNAR NERVE INTEGRITY TEST
